title: 103_hr3810
content: The "Rural Community Wastewater Treatment Affordability Act of 1994" includes provisions for eligibility criteria and capitalization grant agreements related to acquiring lands and rights-of-ways for construction of treatment works, and nonprofit water associations eligible for assistance. The "Rural Community Wastewater Treatment Affordability Act of 1994" amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include encouraging the use of innovative technologies in treatment works construction financed with assistance from the fund. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide loans to rural and disadvantaged communities at or below market interest rates, including interest-free and negative-interest loans, with terms not exceeding 40 years or the project's useful life. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide loans to rural and disadvantaged communities at or below market interest rates, including interest-free and negative-interest loans. Grants are also provided for planning and predevelopment costs incurred by these communities for construction or improvement of treatment works. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide grants to rural and disadvantaged communities for planning and predevelopment costs related to treatment works, with a maximum grant amount of $75,000 per project. The definition of "rural and disadvantaged communities" is also clarified in the Act. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to define "rural and disadvantaged communities" as service areas with a population of less than 10,000 and residents with a median household income below 75% of the national median. It also introduces the term "negative-interest loan" as a zero percent interest loan with forgiveness of up to 2% of the principal for such communities. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act defines a "loan" as a zero percent interest loan with forgiveness of up to 2% of the principal for rural and disadvantaged communities. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to limit administrative costs to 4% of total funds deposited in a fiscal year. SEC. 6 introduces a technical assistance grant program under Title VI of the Act. SEC. 6 introduces a technical assistance grant program under Title VI of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to provide training and assistance to rural and disadvantaged communities for treatment works. $15,000,000 per fiscal year is authorized for this program from 1994 to 1998.
